review.title: Parkinson's Disease Motor Symptoms in Machine Learning: A Review
review.abstract: This paper reviews related work and state-of-the-art publications for recognizing motor symptoms of Parkinson's Disease (PD). It presents research efforts that were undertaken to inform on how well traditional machine learning algorithms can handle this task. In particular, four PD related motor symptoms are highlighted (i.e. tremor, bradykinesia, freezing of gait and dyskinesia) and their details summarized. Thus the primary objective of this research is to provide a literary foundation for development and improvement of algorithms for detecting PD related motor symptoms.
histories: Health Informatics: An International Journal (HIIJ), November 2013, Volume 2, Number 4
review.COMMENTS: Health Informatics: An International Journal (HIIJ), November 2013, Volume 2, Number 4

metadata.title: PARKINSON'S DISEASE MOTOR SYMPTOMS IN MACHINE LEARNING: A REVIEW

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / hiij.2013.2401 1This paper presents related work and current publications on the recognition of motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease (PD), presents research efforts undertaken to inform how well traditional machine learning algorithms can perform this task, and in particular highlights four PD-related motor symptoms (i.e. tremor, bradykinesia, gait freeze and dyskinesia) and summarizes their details. Therefore, the primary objective of this research is to provide a literary basis for the development and improvement of algorithms for the detection of PD-related motor symptoms.KEYWORDSParkinson's disease, machine learning, artificial intelligence, review, state-of-the-art

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where there is only one person who is able to move in order to unfold.

sections.heading: 2. IDENTIFYING PARKINSON'S DISEASE AND ITS SYMPTOMS
sections.text: In the last two decades, an increasing number of publications have emerged from fields such as computer science or AI, focusing on the importance of motor symptoms in people with Parkinson's disease, some of them dedicated to the recognition of individual motor symptoms [63], [66], [54], [7], [45], [39], [21], [14] and others to the recognition of multiple symptoms [57], [15], [55], [50]. These publications show a large number of techniques for automatically indicating the presence of PD motor symptoms (e.g. NNN [30], [5], [21], [16], HMM [54] and SVM [9], [50], [14]).

sections.heading: 2.1. TREMOR AT REST
sections.text: In an early study by Salarian et al. [56], specificity of 98% and sensitivity of 96.6% were achieved on a dataset with ten patients and ten controls, and a total of almost twenty hours of data were collected by the authors. Two tri-axial gyroscopes (i.e. one on each wrist) were used to record data while participants performed a series of scripted everyday activities; spectral analysis was used to filter out interesting regions within the specific frequency range specific to resting tremors (i.e. 3.5 Hz-7.5 Hz); in a later study [57] based on the same dataset, the data stream was divided into chunks with a length of three seconds; in addition, meta meta analysis was introduced to remove isolated segments classified as patients exhibiting tremor-like behavior.

sections.heading: 2.2. BRADYKINESIA
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 2.3. AKINESIA / FREEZING OF GAIT
sections.text: In the second half of the last decade, the number of patients able to walk in the practice doubled; the kinematics of four patients (as they followed a pre-determined path) were collected, commented on and used to train a neural network; in total, about 30 minutes of data was collected covering several (potential) hurdles designed to provoke FOG; target hesitation or hesitation, etc. A combination of heuristically determined thresholds and an NN were used to differentiate between "normal" (i.e.) and pathological steps.

sections.heading: 2.4. DYSKINESIA
sections.text: The results of the study show that the individual subjects were able to perform a series of scripted activities (about 35) in a controlled environment. A total of six three-dimensional accelerometers were attached to the subjects "bodies (i.e. one of them on each thigh, one on each shoulder, one on the wrist).The algorithm, the one by Keijsers et al., classified fifteen-minute segments using a regular neural network.The output of the NN indicated the presence (or absence) of dyskinesia within the segment. Several segment sizes were evaluated empirically (e.g. fifteen and one-minute segments).The best accuracy was achieved with the fifteen-minute segments (i.e. 96.8%).

sections.heading: 2.5 DYSARTHIA AND DYSPHAGIA
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it will happen, until it does.

sections.heading: 2.6 OTHER
sections.text: Their goal was to build a reliable tool that mapped the results of surgeries based on intraoperative recordings of neural activity; to establish a system that provided complementary data and tools to minimize risks (e.g. blindness, difficulty speaking or swallowing, etc.) and maximize their effectiveness; and their results suggest that all evaluated NGOs proceeded in a manner similar to the overall outcomes of patients. Hamilton and his colleagues found that their NGOs handled exceptional cases in terms of diagnosing Kupryjanov et al as an alternative measurement method for determining UPDRS sub-scores in terms of motor tests and fast alternating hand movements.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: This work was motivated and partly funded by the European Commission through the AAL JP Call 1 project HELP and the ICT FP 7 project REMPARK (287677).The authors thank the Commission and the HELP and REMPARK partners for their fruitful work and contribution to research.

metadata.abstractText: This paper reviews related work and state-of-the-art publications for recognizing motor symptoms of Parkinson's Disease (PD). It presents research efforts that were undertaken to inform on how well traditional machine learning algorithms can handle this task. In particular, four PD related motor symptoms are highlighted (i.e. tremor, bradykinesia, freezing of gait and dyskinesia) and their details summarized. Thus the primary objective of this research is to provide a literary foundation for development and improvement of algorithms for detecting PD related motor symptoms.
